description:
A sign of
            relation,
        bringing the clause introduced by it into relation with an antecedent clause. As a rule אֲשֶׁר
        is a
        mere connecting link, and requires to be supplemented (see the grammars) by a pronominal
        affix, or other
        word, such as שָׁם, defining the nature of the relation more precisely

senses.description: it includes its pronominal antecedent, whether in the nominative or oblique cases

instances of אֲשֶׁר followed by a pronominal affix, or by שָׁם,
        שָֽׁמָּה, מִשָּׁם, are so common that the examples cited above will be
        sufficient

sometimes (though rarely) the defining adjunct is a pronoun of 1 or 2 person as well as of 3
        person. In such cases it is strictly to be rendered I who . . ., thou who, etc.
the defining pronominal adjunct is dispensed with

sometimes in poetry = one who, a man who (men who
        )

occasionally receives its closer definition by a substantive following
         it, in other words, its logical antecedent is inserted in the relative clause

׳
אֲשֶׁר ל
that (belongs, belong, belonged) to, is used

אֲשֶׁר becomes, like Aramaic דּי,
        , a conjunction approximating in usage to
        כִּי
